Loneliness is one of the more unexpected feelings that can accompany motherhood, especially in the early days. I know I felt it back in the first stages with Teddy when his dad had gone back to work, mum had gone back to wales and my friends were busy getting on with their own lives whilst I was too scared to leave the house with a newborn. It gets better of course, and with confidence comes the ability to socialise with other mums. Some feel lonely at later stages though and it can creep up on you when you least expect it. The brilliant #mummysocial have opened up that conversation and have said loud and clear that it‚Äôs ok to feel lonely and that most of us have at one time or another. If you have a friend with a baby who you know is home alone all day and you can pop in for 15 mins for a cuppa, do it. I‚Äôll make all the difference. There‚Äôs not much a cuppa and a chat can‚Äôt sort out.

Tonight at 8pm on @bbc2 our factory girls will be making these bright orange flares on the production line as they move to 1973. There were more women than ever in our British workforce by now, but was there any sign of a move towards equality? Our women live the highs and lows of that year. There‚Äôs also a raucous hen night, a day trip to Barry Island and plenty of great 70‚Äôs fashion!! #backintimeforthefactory

Tonight, at 8pm on @bbc2 a brand new series of #backintimeforthefactory will be on your telly. It‚Äôs without doubt one of the most fun programmes I‚Äôve been lucky enough to work on thanks mainly to our fabulous girls who stepped back in time and became factory girls of the 60‚Äôs/70‚Äôs and 80‚Äôs starting tonight in ‚Äò68. Their journey really helps us understand how sacrifices made then still impact on working women today and how their fight improved working conditions for us all. It‚Äôs all done with bucket loads of humour, but these girls are feisty and get properly fired up as they move through each era. There‚Äôs also amazing hair, make up and costumes to whet your vintage appetite. A good watch all round.

Putting the final touches to this special programme we made back in April this morning. #backintimeforthefactory. It‚Äôs on @bbc2 on Thursday the 6th of September. It‚Äôs enlightening, humorous and heartwarming all at once and so timely with all the news on equal pay this year. These girls were the best. They lapped up the experience and transformed effortlessly into factory girls from the 60‚Äôs/70 and 80‚Äôs with clothes make up and hair styles that were just üëåüèª. I hope you love it as much as we enjoyed making it. üë≠

A big chapter in the book is all about postpartum or ‚Äòpost ripped in halfum‚Äô as I call it. After having Teddy, I knew it was going to be bad, but nothing quite prepares you just how exhausted and sore you feel just as your about to embark on a life long marathon. How long did it take you to feel normal again? In all seriousness, it took me the best part of a year to really feel like myself again...even my bone shape had changed and nobody tells you about that. I swear that my ribs are still further apart than they used to be and let‚Äôs not start on the melted ice cream stomach. Happy @sportrelief day!! One last push to try and get our total as high as poss for our #motherofallchallenges. It was a stunning effort from these ladies and a bloody hard week where we faced some big fears and pushed ourselves as far as poss to try and raise cash and awareness for maternal issues. These women have all had a really tough time mostly due to severe post natal depression and we hope that our challenge helped in getting people talking about a difficult subject and realising that there is some help out there. Lots of those projects are funded though by sport relief so for the cost of a bottle of calpol or a box of formula you could be helping a mother who is really struggling to see any light in what should be a joyous time. Please help us to help other mothers. After all we‚Äôre all in it together. Go www.sportrelief.com/mums

So our @sportrelief challenge is out there. üò¨Thanks to these super women for taking part. It‚Äôs gonna be tough, but every penny raised will make it 100% worth it. It‚Äôs great that we‚Äôre doing it as a team and I‚Äôm very grateful to them for volunteering to get involved. Cycling, swimming, hiking, caving and running a marathon in freezing temperatures is no easy feat as well as giving up their precious time to train and agree to be away from their loved ones for the duration of the challenge itself. #themotherofallchallenges #strongertogether oh yes, and that‚Äôs the #topgear boys in the picture. The ladies were very excited about meeting ‚Äòjoey from friends‚Äô

Today, I met the most incredible woman. Her name is Helen and she‚Äôs a midwife. She‚Äôs also plays the part of doctor, teacher, lawyer and mother to all 40 mums and babies that she saw in one single morning. Even in the midst of all the chaos at the busy clinic she made time to talk to us and explain what she did. She clearly loves her job and finds great joy in the fact that she is transforming the lives of families living in the slums in Nairobi one mother at a time. She‚Äôs trying her best to educate women to have their pre and post natal checks at the clinic, as well as giving birth there in safe surroundings but the bigger picture is that the men also need to be educated that proper health care is critical to the wellbeing of their wives, partners and children. We unfortunately met one lady who has suffered because of this specific lack of education. We‚Äôll be telling her story on @bbctheoneshow in the next few weeks. @sportrelief #themotherofallchallenges

So here it is. After a lot of blood, sweat and tears, my book had gone to print and I can finally reveal the cover of ‚ÄòWinging it.‚Äô What a year it‚Äôs been. An epic journey of guessing how to raise a baby whilst writing and editing my first book. I couldn‚Äôt have done it without your support and stories so thank you from the bottom of my heart. It‚Äôs undoubtably been the best year but so bloody hard at times and so this book is a very honest account of the last 18 months. The highs, lows and everything in between. (I‚Äôm worried now that it‚Äôs a bit too close to the knuckle but hey ho, what‚Äôs done is done.) I hope it will be helpful for all you parents-to-be and a good old laugh along tool for readers who are already in the same boat! First things first. This is a TBT this time last year! Thank you so much for every single story that you‚Äôve sent over night. They‚Äôre really bloody excellent and a group effort definitely helps give a fuller picture of an experience that‚Äôs impossible for a single person to capture. Pregnancy stories would also be welcomed with open arms. Whether yours was a breeze or tough from start to finish. How did you feel about your body, did it have an impact on your relationship? What were your main concerns? Maybe you worried about maternity leave? (Did you see the excellent @bbcone #thereplacement) or could it have been financial worries that we‚Äôre bothering you. Tips on how you got through it from sleeping to keeping fit and anything else that you would like to share.
On the subject of sleep or lack of it.....stories of how you coped/are copingin your first year of parenthood (dad‚Äôs too on this one).
Does anybody have tips to getting more zzzzzz‚Äôs? That would be really excellent!
And finally the search for the holy grail, otherwise known as WORK/LIFE balance. Share how you are trying to achieve this nearly impossible scenario. I can‚Äôt wait to read these!!!! (It‚Äôs a daily battle as I‚Äôm sure it is for you.)
Please send to the link in my bio. Thanks a million, Al xx

It‚Äôs been a hell of a journey trying to write a book in the first year of becoming a parent, but I‚Äôm nearly done!! I‚Äôm editing the final draft and it‚Äôs really bloody honest...(I‚Äôm scared üôà) Anyway, a massive thank you to those of you that have send in your parenting stories. They‚Äôre brilliant, and hopefully, with all our efforts combined, it will give parents to be a very rounded picture of what‚Äôs to come whilst comforting the rest of us because we‚Äôre all in it together.
It‚Äôs a bit last minute, but I feel that I would love to include the following stories;
Feeding
A mother who formula fed from the off, be that a decision that was made pre baby or because that was the only option. Breast is obviously awesome but not necessarily best or possible for everyone.
Labour
I talk about my labour at length, but of course, everybody‚Äôs experience is unique, so it would be great to hear from someone who did hypnobirthing lessons and found that they really helped during labour.
Care
There‚Äôs a big chapter on finding the right sort of care for your child if you‚Äôre both working parents. Tips and what worked for you when looking for a cr√®che/nursery or a nanny would be great. Maybe you rely on your parents? Whatever your set up, please be part of the conversation because let‚Äôs face it, going back to work is horrendous and knowing that you have care that you‚Äôre happy with goes some way to making things slightly more manageable.
Relationship
If you‚Äôre brave enough to discuss how a baby has impacted your relationship, then that would be brilliant....I‚Äôm still waiting for the ok from charlie on some of my content.ü§ûüèª
Lastly, your epic parenting fails!
It doesn‚Äôt have to be an essay, just a couple of lines, so if you‚Äôre interested in being included, send away to the address in my bio. I look forward to reading them. Al xx.

Calling all Dads (especially if you're over 35+ and keen to share your experiences in my new book.) Most couples I know can only survive by co-parenting in the true sense of the word and too often, dads are overlooked for anecdotes, tips and tricks. Have you ever heard any one asking a mother whether they're  a 'hands on mum'? No, never! Yet, people are still asking fathers that very same outdated question. Ted and I would be stuffed without Charlie. So come on dads, share your wisdom. How was labour from your perspective, the worries and anxieties you had pre baby and how you felt in the aftermath. How did you handle breast feeding? Did it make you feel excluded? How did you and your partner tackle the nights? Did you decide to be a stay at home dad and how has that panned out? A paragraph, even a sentence would be much appreciated and you might even end up on the cover if you fancy it. Click on the link at the top of my bio and type away. You can use it to vent too if you need to. There's no judgment here. #wereinittogether #wingingit #dads #firsttimedad

Here we go! I'm really nervous about writing this new book. I've never done it before so goodness knows how it'll turn out (winging it in the true sense of the word). I'm also nervous  because, as we know, people are very quick to judge other mums even though all we're doing is trying our best. Anyway, let's give it a go. It's a collaboration between myself and other parents so that's where you come in. I would like you to share your experiences, good and bad. I'd love to hear your birth stories (yep, let's tell it as it really is) how you announced your pregnancy especially if you did it in a fun way, your breastfeeding tales. I'm keen to get dad's and partners involved too. How did you find the birth? Was bonding hard initially? How has it changed your views on each other? How do you balance working and parenting? What's the toughest part? Do you feel that being an older parent (if you are one) has impacted on your experience and how? What positives/negatives does it bring with it? Funny stories would also be most welcome because let's face it....you gotta laugh! That's the key isn't it?
You can send them all....just a couple of sentences or a whole essay, you decide,  to the link on my bio. Big thanks!! #wingingit #we'reallinittogether #parenting #newparents #olderparents #shareexperiences

Having made a documentary all about fertility last year, I realised just how many people, like me, were becoming parents a bit later than expected. Along with the sheer joy of falling pregnant there are also plenty of unexpected twists and turns, and the realisation that most new parents are still pretty lost when it comes to the parenting game, and not just the over 30s. Being a mother is being judged... but in my new book which will be coming out next spring I want myself and lots of other mums and dads to candidly share some of our stand out moments, good and bad. I want the book to help in arming parents to be with some of the surprising facts that nobody tells you, while being a laugh along guide for those experiencing the same highs and lows. We're all in it together.‚Äù Please send in your stories to the email address that‚Äôs in my profile bio and could be featured in Winging It! I look forward to hearing from you üòò. P.s the sweatshirt was a Christmas present from my sister and my friend also bought one for me when Teddy was born so it seemed like the perfect title for the book.
